image.altText: A bunch of gold bars and coins.

items.synopsis: The Federal investigation will probe whetherÂ Australia's reputation in the precious metals industry was damaged by a string of ongoing sagas at the embattled Mint.

title.children: Perth Mint to undergo Federal probe in wake of so-called 'gold doping' saga

image.altText: A dim, dark blue picture of a white submersible underwater, with a stream of bubbles coming from it.

items.synopsis: Authorities say the search for the submersible missing near the Titanic wreck is entering a critical stage, with fears the five occupants will run out of oxygen and develop hypothermia if not found soon. Follow live.

title.children: Search for missing submersible Titan enters critical stage, only hours of oxygen remain

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Frank Owen, a former commander in the Royal Australian Navy who directed its submarine escape and rescue project, says the experienced French diver on board the Titan, Paul-Henri Nargeolet, would be instructing the other passengers as to how to conserve oxygen. "He would say lie down, sleep if you can, minimise your movement, do as little as possible and calm yourself down," Mr Owen told the ABC's RN Drive. "So you don't breathe too much and exhale too much CO2. "The 96 hours [of oxygen] is a nominal estimate based on standard consumption [of a certain amount of] litres per minute. If you can reduce that, you can extend your life. "It's not like a parking meter that will click over at 96 and the oxygen will stop."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: French diver 'would be instructing passengers to conserve oxygen'

children.content: Frank Owen
, a former commander in the Royal Australian Navy who directed its submarine escape and rescue project, says the experienced French diver on board the Titan,
Paul-Henri Nargeolet
, would be instructing the other passengers as to how to conserve oxygen.

props.alt: An older bald man wearing black headphones looks straight ahead into the camera.

children.content: Retired navy submariner Frank Owen (file picture).
(ABC News)
"He would say lie down, sleep if you can, minimise your movement, do as little as possible and calm yourself down," Mr Owen told the ABC's
Â
RN Drive
"So you don't breathe too much and exhale too much CO2.
"The 96 hours [of oxygen] is a nominal estimate based on standard consumption [of a certain amount of] litres per minute. If you can reduce that, you can extend your life.
"It's not like a parking meter that will click over at 96 and the oxygen will stop."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The time it has taken to load some of the heavy equipment needed for a potential rescue effort means there are still ships on the way to the search area, even as the Titan's oxygen supply is likely nearing its end. Among them are the Terry Fox, a Canadian Coast Guard icebreaker carrying search and rescue equipment, and the Horizon Arctic, a Canadian ship with a launch and recovery system for remotely operated submersibles, which is reportedly carring a US military vehicle.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ships are still on their way to the search area

children.content: The time it has taken to load some of the heavy equipment needed for a potential rescue effort means there are still ships on the way to the search area, even as the Titan's oxygen supply is likely nearing its end.
Among them are the
Terry Fox
, a Canadian Coast Guard icebreaker carrying search and rescue equipment, and the
Horizon Arctic
, a Canadian ship with a launch and recovery system for remotely operated submersibles, which is reportedly carring a US military vehicle.

props.alt: A large red and white boat sitting in a foggy port.

children.content: CCGS Terry Fox prepares to depart St John's Port in Newfoundland on Tuesday, local time.
(Reuters)

props.alt: A large, sharp-looking blue boat sits in a foggy port.

children.content: The MV Horizon Arctic sits in St John's Port as equipment is loaded onto it by a US Air Force airlift.
(Reuters)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Boeing has told CNN it "was not a partner on the Titan and did not design or build it ", despite a 2021 news release from OceanGate listing the company as a partner that provided "design and engineering support". Similarly the University of Washington has told local media it was not involved with the design, engineering or testing of the submersible, despite a 2021 OceanGate court filing crediting the university for having taken part in "detailed engineering and development work". A spokesman said the university had worked with OceanGate from 2013 to 2020 on a different submersible called the Cyclops .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Boeing, University of Washington deny they helped design the Titan

did not design or build it

Cyclops
